newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico central bank inflation fight key to growth.
newsitem.headline: Mexico central bank inflation fight key to growth.

text.p: Mexico's central bank reiterated on Tuesday that fighting inflation is the best way it can aid economic growth and help create jobs and boost real salaries.
"The annual inflation rate showed a clear tendency downwards," the central bank said in its annual report for 1996, adding its policies also helped drive down inflationary expectations.
In 1996, the annual inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, was 27.7 percent, after reaching 51.97 percent in 1995.

In its yearly report, Banco de Mexico said its fight against inflation would also help create a greater pool of savings in Mexico, thus helping to weaken market forces as the principle influence on interest rates.
Lower inflation also was a spur for investment.
"In these conditions, foreign and domestic savers can see with greater certainty the real returns they obtain by investing in financial instruments denominated in the local currency," it said.
"Moreover, as prices stabilize, savers will be more ready to hold onto longer-term instruments."
The central bank said consumption and investment also made significant contributions to the economy in 1996, adding to the growth in exports.
It noted financial and exchange markets stabilized substantially last year, saying that peso volatility against the dollar was "reduced in a considerable manner."
The bank said a better macroeconomic picture, as well better perspectives on the economy improved the conditions under which Mexico obtained funds on international capital markets.

The central bank noted that the rise of net international assets by some $5.864 billion during the year was due to increased external debt placements, a higher price of oil that bumped up net reveneus for PEMEX and the dollar option plan that the bank put into place mid-year.
The bank said that, through the dollar option plan, it obtained $909 million in the year, by exercising options worth $930 million that it offered from August to December.
Banco de Mexico said the results of allowing the currency to float could at the end of 1994 "could be considered positive."
It noted there had been fears a floating exchange rate would lead to market volatility.
"The evolution shown by the exchange rate from the start of 1996 did not correspond to this fear," it said.
